member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.Mode
member.summary: An object must be in one of three modes: normal, locked or hidden. If an object is in normal mode, then the object's layer controls visibility and selectability. If an object is locked, then the object's layer controls visibility by the object cannot be selected. If the object is hidden, it is not visible and it cannot be selected.

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.IsInstanceDefinitionObject
member.summary: Use this query to determine if an object is part of an instance definition.

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.Visible
member.summary: object visibility.

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.LinetypeSource
member.summary: The Linetype used to display an object is specified in one of two ways. If LinetypeSource is ON::linetype_from_layer, then the object's layer ON_Layer::Linetype() is used. If LinetypeSource is ON::linetype_from_object, then value of m_linetype is used.

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.ColorSource
member.summary: The color used to display an object is specified in one of three ways. If ColorSource is ON::color_from_layer, then the object's layer ON_Layer::Color() is used. If ColorSource is ON::color_from_object, then value of m_color is used. If ColorSource is ON::color_from_material, then the diffuse color of the object's render material is used. See ON_3dmObjectAttributes::MaterialSource() to determine where to get the definition of the object's render material.

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.PlotColorSource
member.summary: The color used to plot an object on paper is specified in one of three ways. If PlotColorSource is ON::plot_color_from_layer, then the object's layer ON_Layer::PlotColor() is used. If PlotColorSource is ON::plot_color_from_object, then value of PlotColor() is used.

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.ObjectId
member.summary:
Every object has a Guid (globally unique identifier, also known as UUID, or universally unique identifier). The default value is Guid.Empty.
When an object is added to a model, the value is checked. If the value is Guid.Empty, a new Guid is created. If the value is not null but it is already used by another object in the model, a new Guid is created. If the value is not Guid.Empty and it is not used by another object in the model, then that value persists. When an object is updated, by a move for example, the value of ObjectId persists.
This value is the same as the one returned by object.Id.

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.Name
member.summary:
Gets or sets an object optional text name.
More than one object in a model can have the same name and some objects may have no name.

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.LayerIndex
member.summary:
Gets or sets an associated layer index.
Layer definitions in an OpenNURBS model are stored in a layer table. The layer table is conceptually an array of ON_Layer classes. Every OpenNURBS object in a model is on some layer. The object's layer is specified by zero based indicies into the ON_Layer array.

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.LinetypeIndex
member.summary:
Gets or sets the linetype index.
Linetype definitions in an OpenNURBS model are stored in a linetype table. The linetype table is conceptually an array of ON_Linetype classes. Every OpenNURBS object in a model references some linetype. The object's linetype is specified by zero based indicies into the ON_Linetype array.
Index 0 is reserved for continuous linetype (no pattern).

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.MaterialIndex
member.summary:
Gets or sets the material index.
If you want something simple and fast, set the index of the rendering material.

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.MaterialSource
member.summary: Determines if the simple material should come from the object or from it's layer. High quality rendering plug-ins should use m_rendering_attributes.

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.Decals
member.summary: Gets all object decals associated with this object.

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.MaterialRefs
member.summary:
If you are developing a high quality plug-in renderer, and a user is assigning a custom render material to this object, then add rendering material information to the MaterialRefs dictionary.
Note to developers: As soon as the MaterialRefs dictionary contains items rendering material queries slow down. Do not populate the MaterialRefs dictionary when setting the MaterialIndex will take care of your needs.

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.ObjectColor
member.summary: If ON::color_from_object == ColorSource, then color is the object's display color.

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.PlotColor
member.summary: If plot_color_from_object == PlotColorSource, then PlotColor is the object's plotting color.

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.HasMapping
member.summary: A mapping from any plugin source is associated with these attributes Need to do this here to respond correctly to ModifyObjectAttributes event

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.DisplayOrder
member.summary:
Display order used to force objects to be drawn on top or behind each other. Larger numbers draw on top of smaller numbers.
0 = draw object in standard depth buffered order
<0 = draw object behind "normal" draw order objects
>0 = draw object on top of "normal" draw order objects

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.PlotWeight
member.summary: Plot weight in millimeters. =0.0 means use the default width <0.0 means don't plot (visible for screen display, but does not show on plot)

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.ObjectDecoration
member.summary: Used to indicate an object has a decoration (like an arrowhead on a curve)

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.WireDensity
member.summary: When a surface object is displayed in wireframe, this controls how many isoparametric wires are used. value number of isoparametric wires -1 boundary wires (off) 0 boundary and knot wires 1 boundary and knot wires and, if there are no interior knots, a single interior wire. N>=2 boundary and knot wires and (N+1) interior wires.

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.ViewportId
member.summary: If ViewportId is nil, the object is active in all viewports. If ViewportId is not nil, then this object is only active in a specific view. This field is primarily used to assign page space objects to a specific page, but it can also be used to restrict model space to a specific view.

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.Space
member.summary: Starting with V4, objects can be in either model space or page space. If an object is in page space, then ViewportId is not nil and identifies the page it is on.

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjectAttributes.GroupCount
member.summary: number of groups object belongs to.

member.name: T:Rhino.Display.RhinoView
member.summary: A RhinoView represents a single "window" display of a document. A view could contain one or many RhinoViewports (many in the case of Layout views with detail viewports). Standard Rhino modeling views have one viewport.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.RhinoView.Redraw
member.summary: Redraws this view.
member.remarks: If you change something in "this" view like the projection, construction plane, background bitmap, etc., then you need to call RhinoView.Redraw() to redraw "this" view./ The other views will not be changed. If you change something in the document (like adding new geometry to the model), then you need to call RhinoDoc.Views.Redraw() to redraw all the views.

member.name: M:Rhino.Input.Custom.PickContext.UpdateClippingPlanes
member.summary: Updates the clipping plane information in pick region. The SetClippingPlanes and View fields must be called before calling UpdateClippingPlanes().

member.name: M:Rhino.Input.Custom.PickContext.PickFrustumTest(Rhino.Geometry.BoundingBox,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Fast test to check if a bounding box intersects a pick frustum.
member.param: Set to true if the box is completely contained in the pick frustum. When doing a window or crossing pick, you can immediately return a hit if the object's bounding box is completely inside of the pick frustum.
member.returns: False if bbox is invalid or box does not intersect the pick frustum

member.name: M:Rhino.Input.Custom.PickContext.PickFrustumTest(Rhino.Geometry.Point3d,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Utility for picking 3d point
member.param: depth returned here for point picks. LARGER values are NEARER to the camera. SMALLER values are FARTHER from the camera.
planar distance returned here for point picks. SMALLER values are CLOSER to the pick point
member.returns: true if there is a hit

member.name: M:Rhino.Input.Custom.PickContext.PickFrustumTest(Rhino.Geometry.Mesh,Rhino.Input.Custom.PickContext.MeshPickStyle,Rhino.Geometry.Point3d@,Rhino.Geometry.Point2d@,Rhino.Geometry.Point2d@,System.Double@,System.Double@,Rhino.Input.Custom.PickContext.MeshHitFlag@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Utility for picking meshes
member.param: location returned here for point picks
If the mesh has surface parameters, set to the surface parameters of the hit point

If the mesh has texture coordinates, set to the texture coordinate of the hit point. Note that the texture coodinates can be set in many different ways and this information is useless unless you know how the texture coordinates are set on this particular mesh.
depth returned here for point picks LARGER values are NEARER to the camera. SMALLER values are FARTHER from the camera.
planar distance returned here for point picks. SMALLER values are CLOSER to the pick point
For point picks, How to interpret the hitIndex (vertex hit, edge hit, or face hit)

member.name: M:Rhino.PlugIns.PlugIn.GetLicense(Rhino.PlugIns.LicenseBuildType,Rhino.PlugIns.ValidateProductKeyDelegate)
member.summary: Verifies that there is a valid product license for your plug-in, using the Rhino licensing system. If the plug-in is installed as a standalone node, the locally installed license will be validated. If the plug-in is installed as a network node, a loaner license will be requested by the system's assigned Zoo server. If the Zoo server finds and returns a license, then this license will be validated. If no license is found, then the user will be prompted to provide a license key, which will be validated.
member.param: The product build contentType required by your plug-in.

Since the Rhino licensing system knows nothing about your product license, you will need to validate the product license provided by the Rhino licensing system. This is done by supplying a callback function, or delegate, that can be called to perform the validation.
member.returns: true if a valid license was found. false otherwise.

member.name: M:Rhino.PlugIns.PlugIn.GetLicense(Rhino.PlugIns.LicenseCapabilities,System.String,Rhino.PlugIns.ValidateProductKeyDelegate)
member.summary: Verifies that there is a valid product license for your plug-in, using the Rhino licensing system. If the plug-in is installed as a standalone node, the locally installed license will be validated. If the plug-in is installed as a network node, a loaner license will be requested by the system's assigned Zoo server. If the Zoo server finds and returns a license, then this license will be validated. If no license is found, then the user will be prompted to provide a license key, which will be validated.
member.param: In the event that a license was not found, or if the user wants to change the way your plug-in is licenses, then provide what capabilities your license has by using this enumeration flag.

In the event that the user needs to be asked for a license, then you can provide a text mask, which helps the user to distinguish between proper and improper user input of your license code. Note, if you do not want to use a text mask, then pass in a null value for this parameter. For more information on text masks, search MSDN for the System.Windows.Forms.MaskedTextBox class.

Since the Rhino licensing system knows nothing about your product license, you will need to validate the product license provided by the Rhino licensing system. This is done by supplying a callback function, or delegate, that can be called to perform the validation.
member.returns: true if a valid license was found. false otherwise.

member.name: M:Rhino.PlugIns.PlugIn.ReturnLicense
member.summary: Returns, or releases, a product license that was obtained from the Rhino licensing system. Note, most plug-ins do not need to call this as the Rhino licensing system will return all licenses when Rhino shuts down.

member.name: M:Rhino.PlugIns.RenderPlugIn.CreatePreview(Rhino.Render.CreatePreviewEventArgs)
member.summary:
Creates the preview bitmap that will appear in the content editor's thumbnail display when previewing materials and environments. If this function is not overridden or the PreviewImage is not set on the args, then the internal OpenGL renderer will generate a simulation of the content.
This function is called with four different preview quality settings. The first quality level of RealtimeQuick is called on the main thread and needs to be drawn as fast as possible. This function is called with the other three quality settings on a separate thread and are meant for generating progressively refined preview.
member.param: Event argument with several preview option state properties.

member.name: M:Rhino.PlugIns.RenderPlugIn.CreateTexture2dPreview(Rhino.Render.CreateTexture2dPreviewEventArgs)
member.summary:
Creates the preview bitmap that will appear in the content editor's thumbnail display when previewing textures in 2d (UV) mode.
If this function is not overridden or the PreviewImage is not set on the args, then the internal OpenGL renderer will generate a simulation.
member.param: Event argument with several preview option state properties.

member.name: P:Rhino.PlugIns.DigitizerPlugIn.PointTolerance
member.summary: The point tolerance is the distance the digitizer must move (in digitizer coordinates) for a new point to be considered real rather than noise. Small desktop digitizer arms have values like 0.001 inches and 0.01 millimeters. This value should never be smaller than the accuracy of the digitizing device.

member.name: P:Rhino.PlugIns.LicenseStatus.ExpirationDate
member.summary: The date and time the license will expire. This value can be null if: 1.) The license contentType is "Standalone" and the license does not expire. 2.) The license contentType is "Network". 3.) The license contentType is "NetworkCheckedOut" and the checkout does not expire Note, date and time is in local time coordinates.

member.name: P:Rhino.PlugIns.LicenseStatus.CheckOutExpirationDate
member.summary: The date and time the checked out license will expire. Note, this is only set if m_license_type = LicenceType.Standalone and if "limited license checkout" was enabled on the Zoo server. Note, date and time is in local time coordinates.

member.name: M:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjRef.Finalize
member.summary: Passively reclaims unmanaged resources when the class user did not explicitly call Dispose().

member.name: M:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjRef.Dispose
member.summary: Actively reclaims unmanaged resources that this instance uses.

member.name: M:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjRef.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary:
For derived class implementers.
This method is called with argument true when class user calls Dispose(), while with argument false when the Garbage Collector invokes the finalizer, or Finalize() method.
You must reclaim all used unmanaged resources in both cases, and can use this chance to call Dispose on disposable fields if the argument is true.
Also, you must call the base virtual method within your overriding method.
member.param: true if the call comes from the Dispose() method; false if it comes from the Garbage Collector finalizer.

member.name: M:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjRef.Object
member.summary: Returns the referenced Rhino object.

member.name: M:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjRef.SelectionMethod
member.summary: Gets the method used to select this object.
member.returns: The method used to select this object.

member.name: M:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjRef.SelectionPoint
member.summary: If the object was selected by picking a point on it, then SelectionPoint() returns the point where the selection occured, otherwise it returns Point3d.Unset.
member.returns: The point where the selection occured or Point3d.Unset on failure.

member.name: M:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjRef.CurveParameter(System.Double@)
member.summary: If the reference geometry is a curve or edge with a selection point, then this gets the parameter of the selection point.
member.param: The parameter of the selection point.
member.returns: If the selection point was on a curve or edge, then the curve/edge is returned, otherwise null.
member.remarks: If a curve was selected and CurveParameter is called and the SelectionMethod() is not 1 (point pick on object), the curve will be returned and parameter will be set to the start parameter of the picked curve. This can be misleading so it may be necessary to call SelectionMethod() first, before calling CurveParameter to get the desired information.

member.name: M:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjRef.SurfaceParameter(System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: If the reference geometry is a surface, brep with one face, or surface edge with a selection point, then this gets the surface paramters of the selection point.
member.param: The U value is assigned to this out parameter during the call.
The V value is assigned to this out parameter during the call.
member.returns: If the selection point was on a surface, then the surface is returned.

member.name: M:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjRef.SetSelectionComponent(Rhino.Geometry.ComponentIndex)
member.summary: When an object is selected by picking a sub-object, SetSelectionComponent may be used to identify the sub-object.

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjRef.ObjectId
member.summary: Returns the id of the referenced Rhino object.

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjRef.RuntimeSerialNumber
member.summary: If > 0, then this is the value of a Rhino object's serial number field. The serial number is used instead of the pointer to prevent crashes in cases when the RhinoObject is deleted but an ObjRef continues to reference the Rhino object. The value of RuntimeSerialNumber is not saved in archives because it generally changes if you save and reload an archive.

member.name: P:Rhino.DocObjects.ObjRef.GeometryComponentIndex
member.summary: Gets the component index of the referenced (sub) geometry. Some objects have subobjects that are valid pieces of geometry. For example, breps have edges and faces that are valid curves and surfaces. Each subobject has a component index that is > 0. The parent geometry has a component index = -1.

member.name: M:Rhino.Geometry.Interval.op_LessThan(Rhino.Geometry.Interval,Rhino.Geometry.Interval)
member.summary:
Determines whether the first specified comes before (has inferior sorting value than) the second Interval.
The lower bound has first evaluation priority.
member.returns: true if a[0] is smaller than b[0], or a[0] == b[0] and a[1] is smaller than b[1]; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:Rhino.Geometry.Interval.op_LessThanOrEqual(Rhino.Geometry.Interval,Rhino.Geometry.Interval)
member.summary:
Determines whether the first specified comes before (has inferior sorting value than) the second Interval, or is equal to it.
The lower bound has first evaluation priority.
member.returns: true if a[0] is smaller than b[0], or a[0] == b[0] and a[1] is smaller than or equal to b[1]; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:Rhino.Geometry.Interval.op_GreaterThan(Rhino.Geometry.Interval,Rhino.Geometry.Interval)
member.summary:
Determines whether the first specified comes after (has superior sorting value than) the second Interval.
The lower bound has first evaluation priority.
member.returns: true if a[0] is larger than b[0], or a[0] == b[0] and a[1] is larger than b[1]; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:Rhino.Geometry.Interval.op_GreaterThanOrEqual(Rhino.Geometry.Interval,Rhino.Geometry.Interval)
member.summary:
Determines whether the first specified comes after (has superior sorting value than) the second Interval, or is equal to it.
The lower bound has first evaluation priority.
member.returns: true if a[0] is larger than b[0], or a[0] == b[0] and a[1] is larger than or equal to b[1]; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:Rhino.Geometry.Interval.CompareTo(Rhino.Geometry.Interval)
member.summary:
Compares this with another interval.
The lower bound has first evaluation priority.
member.returns:
0: if this is identical to other
-1: if this[0] < other[0]
+1: if this[0] > other[0]
-1: if this[0] == other[0] and this[1] < other[1]
+1: if this[0] == other[0] and this[1] > other[1].

member.name: M:Rhino.Geometry.Interval.FromIntersection(Rhino.Geometry.Interval,Rhino.Geometry.Interval)
member.summary: Returns a new Interval that is the Intersection of the two input Intervals.
member.returns: If the intersection is not empty, then intersection = [max(a.Min(),b.Min()), min(a.Max(),b.Max())] The interval [ON.UnsetValue,ON.UnsetValue] is considered to be the empty set interval. The result of any intersection involving an empty set interval or disjoint intervals is the empty set interval.

member.name: M:Rhino.Geometry.Interval.FromUnion(Rhino.Geometry.Interval,Rhino.Geometry.Interval)
member.summary: Returns a new Interval which contains both inputs.
member.returns:
The union of an empty set and an increasing interval is the increasing interval.
The union of two empty sets is empty.
The union of an empty set an a non-empty interval is the non-empty interval.
The union of two non-empty intervals is [min(a.Min(),b.Min()), max(a.Max(),b.Max())]

member.name: M:Rhino.Geometry.Interval.EpsilonEquals(Rhino.Geometry.Interval,System.Double)
member.summary: Check that all values in other are within epsilon of the values in this

Determines whether the first specified point comes before (has inferior sorting value than) the second point.
Coordinates evaluation priority is first X, then Y.

member.name: M:Rhino.Geometry.Point2d.op_LessThanOrEqual(Rhino.Geometry.Point2d,Rhino.Geometry.Point2d)

Determines whether the first specified point comes before (has inferior sorting value than) the second point, or it is equal to it.
Coordinates evaluation priority is first X, then Y.

member.name: M:Rhino.Geometry.Point2d.op_GreaterThan(Rhino.Geometry.Point2d,Rhino.Geometry.Point2d)

Determines whether the first specified comes after (has superior sorting value than) the second point.

member.name: M:Rhino.Geometry.Point2d.op_GreaterThanOrEqual(Rhino.Geometry.Point2d,Rhino.Geometry.Point2d)

member.name: M:Rhino.Geometry.Point3d.SortAndCullPointList(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Rhino.Geometry.Point3d},System.Double)
member.summary:
Orders a set of points so they will be connected in a "reasonable polyline" order.
Also, removes points from the list if their common distance exceeds a specified threshold.

Minimum allowed distance among a pair of points. If points are closer than this, only one of them will be kept.
member.returns: The new array of sorted and culled points.

member.name: M:Rhino.Geometry.Vector2d.op_LessThan(Rhino.Geometry.Vector2d,Rhino.Geometry.Vector2d)
member.summary:
Determines whether the first specified vector comes before (has inferior sorting value than) the second vector.
Components have decreasing evaluation priority: first X, then Y.
member.returns: true if a.X is smaller than b.X, or a.X == b.X and a.Y is smaller than b.Y; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:Rhino.Geometry.Vector2d.op_LessThanOrEqual(Rhino.Geometry.Vector2d,Rhino.Geometry.Vector2d)
member.summary:
Determines whether the first specified vector comes before (has inferior sorting value than) the second vector, or it is equal to it.
Components have decreasing evaluation priority: first X, then Y.
member.returns: true if a.X is smaller than b.X, or a.X == b.X and a.Y <= b.Y; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:Rhino.Geometry.Vector2d.op_GreaterThan(Rhino.Geometry.Vector2d,Rhino.Geometry.Vector2d)
member.summary:
Determines whether the first specified vector comes after (has superior sorting value than) the second vector.
Components have decreasing evaluation priority: first X, then Y.
member.returns: true if a.X is larger than b.X, or a.X == b.X and a.Y is larger than b.Y; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:Rhino.Geometry.Vector2d.op_GreaterThanOrEqual(Rhino.Geometry.Vector2d,Rhino.Geometry.Vector2d)
member.summary:
Determines whether the first specified vector comes after (has superior sorting value than) the second vector, or it is equal to it.
Components have decreasing evaluation priority: first X, then Y.
member.returns: true if a.X is larger than b.X, or a.X == b.X and a.Y >= b.Y; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:Rhino.Geometry.Vector3d.op_Multiply(Rhino.Geometry.Vector3d,Rhino.Geometry.Vector3d)
member.summary: Multiplies two vectors together, returning the dot product (or inner product). This differs from the cross product.
member.returns:
A value that results from the evaluation of v1.X*v2.X + v1.Y*v2.Y + v1.Z*v2.Z.
This value equals v1.Length * v2.Length * cos(alpha), where alpha is the angle between vectors.

member.name: M:Rhino.Geometry.Vector3d.Multiply(Rhino.Geometry.Vector3d,Rhino.Geometry.Vector3d)
member.summary:

member.returns:
A value that results from the evaluation of v1.X*v2.X + v1.Y*v2.Y + v1.Z*v2.Z.
This value equals v1.Length * v2.Length * cos(alpha), where alpha is the angle between vectors.

member.name: M:Rhino.Geometry.Vector3d.CrossProduct(Rhino.Geometry.Vector3d,Rhino.Geometry.Vector3d)
member.summary:
Computes the cross product (or vector product, or exterior product) of two vectors.
This operation is not commutative.
member.returns:
A new vector that is perpendicular to both a and b,
has Length == a.Length * b.Length and
with a result that is oriented following the right hand rule.

member.name: M:Rhino.RhinoApp.RunScript(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Runs a Rhino command script.
member.param: Controls how the script is echoed in the command output window. false = silent - nothing is echoed. true = verbatim - the script is echoed literally.
member.remarks: Rhino acts as if each character in the script string had been typed in the command prompt. When RunScript is called from a "script runner" command, it completely runs the script before returning. When RunScript is called outside of a command, it returns and the script is run. This way menus and buttons can use RunScript to execute complicated functions.
member.exception: If RunScript is being called while inside an event watcher.

member.name: M:Rhino.RhinoApp.RunScript(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Runs a Rhino command script.

When RunScript is called from a "script runner" command, it completely runs the script before returning. When RunScript is called outside of a command, it returns and the script is run. This way menus and buttons can use RunScript to execute complicated functions.
member.exception: If RunScript is being called while inside an event watcher.

member.name: M:Rhino.RhinoApp.GetPlugInObject(System.Guid)
member.summary: Gets the object that is returned by PlugIn.GetPlugInObject for a given plug-in. This function attempts to find and load a plug-in with a given Id. When a plug-in is found, it's GetPlugInObject function is called and the result is returned here. Note the plug-in must have already been installed in Rhino or the plug-in manager will not know where to look for a plug-in with a matching id.
member.returns: Result of PlugIn.GetPlugInObject for a given plug-in on success.

member.name: M:Rhino.RhinoApp.GetPlugInObject(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the object that is returned by PlugIn.GetPlugInObject for a given plug-in. This function attempts to find and load a plug-in with a given name. When a plug-in is found, it's GetPlugInObject function is called and the result is returned here. Note the plug-in must have already been installed in Rhino or the plug-in manager will not know where to look for a plug-in with a matching name.
member.returns: Result of PlugIn.GetPlugInObject for a given plug-in on success.

member.name: P:Rhino.RhinoApp.SdkVersion
member.summary:
Rhino SDK 9 digit SDK version number in the form YYYYMMDDn
Rhino will only load plug-ins that were build with exactly the same version of the SDK.

member.name: P:Rhino.RhinoApp.SdkServiceRelease
member.summary:
Rhino SDK 9 digit SDK service release number in the form YYYYMMDDn
Service service release of the Rhino SDK supported by this executable. Rhino will only load plug-ins that require a service release of <= this release number. For example, SR1 will load all plug-ins made with any SDK released up through and including the SR1 SDK. But, SR1 will not load a plug-in built using the SR2 SDK. If an "old" Rhino tries to load a "new" plug-in, the user is told that they have to get a free Rhino.exe update in order for the plug-in to load. Rhino.exe updates are available from http://www.rhino3d.com.

member.name: P:Rhino.RhinoApp.ExeServiceRelease

member.name: M:Rhino.RhinoMath.IsValidDouble(System.Double)
member.summary:
Determines whether a value is valid within the RhinoCommon context.
Rhino does not use Double.NaN by convention, so this test evaluates to true if:
x is not equal to RhinoMath.UnsetValue
System.Double.IsNaN(x) evaluates to false
System.Double.IsInfinity(x) evaluates to false
member.returns: true if the number if valid, false if the number is NaN, Infinity or Unset.

member.name: M:Rhino.RhinoMath.IsValidSingle(System.Single)
member.summary:
Determines whether a value is valid within the RhinoCommon context.
Rhino does not use Single.NaN by convention, so this test evaluates to true if:
x is not equal to RhinoMath.UnsetValue,
System.Single.IsNaN(x) evaluates to false
System.Single.IsInfinity(x) evaluates to false
member.returns: true if the number if valid, false if the number is NaN, Infinity or Unset.

member.name: F:Rhino.UnitSystem.Astronomical
member.summary: Astronomical unit distance. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomical_unit 1.495979e+11 // http://units.nist.gov/Pubs/SP811/appenB9.htm An astronomical unit (au) is the mean distance from the center of the earth to the center of the sun.

member.name: F:Rhino.UnitSystem.Lightyears
member.summary:
Light Year
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Light_year 9.46073e+15 meters http://units.nist.gov/Pubs/SP811/appenB9.htm
A light year is the distance light travels in one Julian year. The speed of light is exactly 299792458 meters/second. A Julian year is exactly 365.25 * 86400 seconds and is approximately the time it takes for one earth orbit.

member.name: T:Rhino.Geometry.Continuity
member.summary: Provides enumerated values for continuity along geometry, such as continuous first derivative or continuous unit tangent and curvature.

member.name: F:Rhino.Geometry.Continuity.None
member.summary: There is no continuity.

member.name: F:Rhino.Geometry.Continuity.C0_continuous
member.summary: Continuous Function : Test for parametric continuity. In particular, all types of curves are considered infinitely continuous at the start/end of the evaluation domain.

member.name: F:Rhino.Geometry.Continuity.C1_continuous
member.summary: Continuous first derivative : Test for parametric continuity. In particular, all types of curves are considered infinitely continuous at the start/end of the evaluation domain.

member.name: F:Rhino.Geometry.Continuity.C2_continuous
member.summary: Continuous first derivative and second derivative : Test for parametric continuity. In particular, all types of curves are considered infinitely continuous at the start/end of the evaluation domain.

member.name: F:Rhino.Geometry.Continuity.G1_continuous
member.summary: Continuous unit tangent : Test for parametric continuity. In particular, all types of curves are considered infinitely continuous at the start/end of the evaluation domain.

member.name: F:Rhino.Geometry.Continuity.G2_continuous
member.summary: Continuous unit tangent and curvature : Test for parametric continuity. In particular, all types of curves are considered infinitely continuous at the start/end of the evaluation domain.

member.name: F:Rhino.Geometry.Continuity.C0_locus_continuous
member.summary: Locus continuous function : Continuity tests using the following enum values are identical to tests using the preceding enum values on the INTERIOR of a curve's domain. At the END of a curve a "locus" test is performed in place of a parametric test. In particular, at the END of a domain, all open curves are locus discontinuous. At the END of a domain, all closed curves are at least C0_locus_continuous. By convention all Curves are considered locus continuous at the START of the evaluation domain. This convention is not strictly correct, but it was adopted to make iterative kink finding tools easier to use and so that locus discontinuities are reported once at the end parameter of a curve rather than twice.

member.name: F:Rhino.Geometry.Continuity.C1_locus_continuous
member.summary: Locus continuous first derivative : Continuity tests using the following enum values are identical to tests using the preceding enum values on the INTERIOR of a curve's domain. At the END of a curve a "locus" test is performed in place of a parametric test. In particular, at the END of a domain, all open curves are locus discontinuous. At the END of a domain, all closed curves are at least C0_locus_continuous. By convention all Curves are considered locus continuous at the START of the evaluation domain. This convention is not strictly correct, but it was adopted to make iterative kink finding tools easier to use and so that locus discontinuities are reported once at the end parameter of a curve rather than twice.

member.name: F:Rhino.Geometry.Continuity.C2_locus_continuous
member.summary: Locus continuous first and second derivative : Continuity tests using the following enum values are identical to tests using the preceding enum values on the INTERIOR of a curve's domain. At the END of a curve a "locus" test is performed in place of a parametric test. In particular, at the END of a domain, all open curves are locus discontinuous. At the END of a domain, all closed curves are at least C0_locus_continuous. By convention all Curves are considered locus continuous at the START of the evaluation domain. This convention is not strictly correct, but it was adopted to make iterative kink finding tools easier to use and so that locus discontinuities are reported once at the end parameter of a curve rather than twice.

member.name: F:Rhino.Geometry.Continuity.G1_locus_continuous
member.summary: Locus continuous unit tangent : Continuity tests using the following enum values are identical to tests using the preceding enum values on the INTERIOR of a curve's domain. At the END of a curve a "locus" test is performed in place of a parametric test. In particular, at the END of a domain, all open curves are locus discontinuous. At the END of a domain, all closed curves are at least C0_locus_continuous. By convention all Curves are considered locus continuous at the START of the evaluation domain. This convention is not strictly correct, but it was adopted to make iterative kink finding tools easier to use and so that locus discontinuities are reported once at the end parameter of a curve rather than twice.

member.summary: Locus continuous unit tangent and curvature : Continuity tests using the following enum values are identical to tests using the preceding enum values on the INTERIOR of a curve's domain. member.name: T:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject
member.summary: The GetObject class is the tool commands use to interactively select objects.

member.name: M:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.CustomGeometryFilter(Rhino.DocObjects.RhinoObject,Rhino.Geometry.GeometryBase,Rhino.Geometry.ComponentIndex)
member.summary: Checks geometry to see if it can be selected. Override to provide fancy filtering.
member.param: if >= 0, geometry is a proper sub-part of object->Geometry() with componentIndex.
member.returns: The default returns true unless you've set a custom geometry filter. If a custom filter has been set, that delegate is called

member.name: M:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.SetCustomGeometryFilter(Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObjectGeometryFilter)
member.summary: Set filter callback function that will be called by the CustomGeometryFilter

member.name: M:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.PassesGeometryAttributeFilter(Rhino.DocObjects.RhinoObject,Rhino.Geometry.GeometryBase,Rhino.Geometry.ComponentIndex)
member.summary: Checks geometry to see if it passes the basic GeometryAttributeFilter.
member.param: if >= 0, geometry is a proper sub-part of object->Geometry() with componentIndex.
member.returns: true if the geometry passes the filter returned by GeometryAttributeFilter().

member.name: M:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.EnablePreSelect(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Control the pre selection behavior GetObjects.
member.param: If true and some acceptable objects are pre-selected, then any unacceptable pre-selected objects are ignored. If false and any unacceptable are pre-selected, then the user is forced to post-select.
member.remarks: By default, if valid input is pre-selected when GetObjects() is called, then that input is returned and the user is not given the opportunity to post-select. If you want to force the user to post-select, then call EnablePreSelect(false).

member.name: M:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.EnablePostSelect(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Control the availability of post selection in GetObjects.
member.remarks: By default, if no valid input is pre-selected when GetObjects is called, then the user is given the chance to post select. If you want to force the user to pre-select, then call EnablePostSelect(false).

member.name: M:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.EnableSelPrevious(System.Boolean)
member.summary: By default, any object selected during a command becomes part of the "previous selection set" and can be reselected by the SelPrev command. If you need to select objects but do not want them to be selected by a subsquent call to SelPrev, then call EnableSelPrev = false.

member.name: M:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.EnableHighlight(System.Boolean)
member.summary: By default, any object post-pick selected by GetObjects() is highlighted. If you want to post-pick objects and not have them automatically highlight, then call EnableHighlight = false.

member.name: M:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.EnableIgnoreGrips(System.Boolean)
member.summary: By default, post selection will select objects with grips on. If you do not want to be able to post select objects with grips on, then call EnableIgnoreGrips = false. The ability to preselect an object with grips on is determined by the value returned by the virtual RhinoObject.IsSelectableWithGripsOn.

member.name: M:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.EnablePressEnterWhenDonePrompt(System.Boolean)
member.summary: By default, when GetObject.GetObjects is called with minimumNumber > 0 and maximumNumber = 0, the command prompt automatically includes "Press Enter when done" after the user has selected at least minimumNumber of objects. If you want to prohibit the addition of the "Press Enter when done", then call EnablePressEnterWhenDonePrompt = false;

member.name: M:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.SetPressEnterWhenDonePrompt(System.String)
member.summary: The default prompt when EnablePressEnterWhenDonePrompt is enabled is "Press Enter when done". Use this function to specify a different string to be appended.
member.param: The text that will be displayed just after the prompt, after the selection has been made.

member.name: M:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.Get
member.summary: Call to select a single object.
member.returns: Success - objects selected. Cancel - user pressed ESCAPE to cancel the get. See GetResults for other possible values that may be returned when options, numbers, etc., are acceptable responses.

member.name: M:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.GetMultiple(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Call to select objects.
member.param: minimum number of objects to select.

maximum number of objects to select. If 0, then the user must press enter to finish object selection. If -1, then object selection stops as soon as there are at least minimumNumber of object selected. If >0, then the picking stops when there are maximumNumber objects. If a window pick, crossing pick, or Sel* command attempts to add more than maximumNumber, then the attempt is ignored.
member.returns: Success - objects selected. Cancel - user pressed ESCAPE to cancel the get. See GetResults for other possible values that may be returned when options, numbers, etc., are acceptable responses.

member.name: M:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.EnableClearObjectsOnEntry(System.Boolean)
member.summary: By default the picked object list is cleared when GetObject.GetObjects() is called. If you are reusing a GetObject class and do not want the existing object list cleared when you call Input, then call EnableClearObjectsOnEntry(false) before calling GetObjects().

member.name: M:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.EnableUnselectObjectsOnExit(System.Boolean)
member.summary: By default any objects in the object list are unselected when GetObject.GetObjects() exits with any return code besides Object. If you want to leave the objects selected when non-object input is returned, then call EnableUnselectObjectsOnExit(false) before calling GetObjects().

member.name: P:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.GeometryFilter
member.summary: The geometry type filter controls which types of geometry (points, curves, surfaces, meshes, etc.) can be selected. The default geometry type filter permits selection of all types of geometry. NOTE: the filter can be a bitwise combination of multiple ObjectTypes.

member.name: P:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.GeometryAttributeFilter
member.summary: The geometry attribute filter provides a secondary filter that can be used to restrict which objects can be selected. Control of the type of geometry (points, curves, surfaces, meshes, etc.) is provided by GetObject.SetGeometryFilter. The geometry attribute filter is used to require the selected geometry to have certain attributes (open, closed, etc.). The default attribute filter permits selection of all types of geometry.

member.name: P:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.DeselectAllBeforePostSelect
member.summary: true if pre-selected input will be deselected before post-selection begins when no pre-selected input is valid.

member.name: P:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.OneByOnePostSelect
member.summary: In one-by-one post selection, the user is forced to select objects by post picking them one at a time.

member.name: P:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.SubObjectSelect
member.summary: By default, GetObject.Input will permit a user to select sub-objects (like a curve in a b-rep or a curve in a group). If you only want the user to select "top" level objects, then call EnableSubObjectSelect = false.

member.name: P:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.ChooseOneQuestion
member.summary: By default, if a call to Input is permitted to select different parts of the same object, like a polysurface and an edge of that polysurface, then the top-most object is automatically selected. If you want the choose-one-object mechanism to include pop up in these cases, then call EnableChooseOneQuestion = true before calling GetObjects().

member.name: P:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.BottomObjectPreference
member.summary: By default, if a call to Input is permitted to select different parts of the same object, like a polysurface, a surface and an edge, then the top-most object is prefered. (polysurface beats face beats edge). If you want the bottom most object to be prefered, then call EnableBottomObjectPreference = true before calling GetObjects().

member.name: P:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.GroupSelect
member.summary: By default, groups are ignored in GetObject. If you want your call to GetObjects() to select every object in a group that has any objects selected, then enable group selection.

member.name: P:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.InactiveDetailPickEnabled
member.summary: By default, objects in inactive details are not permitted to be picked. In a few rare cases this is used (ex. picking circles during DimRadius)

member.name: P:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.ReferenceObjectSelect
member.summary: By default, reference objects can be selected. If you do not want to be able to select reference objects, then call EnableReferenceObjectSelect=false.

member.name: P:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.AlreadySelectedObjectSelect
member.summary: Allow selecting objects that are already selected. By default, GetObjects() disallows selection of objects that are already selected to avoid putting the same object in the selection set more than once. Calling EnableAlreadySelectedObjectSelect = true overrides that restriction and allows selected objects to be selected and returned by GetObjects. This is useful because, coupled with the return immediately mode of GetObjects(1, -1), it is possible to select a selected object to deselect when the selected objects are being managed outside GetObjects() as in the case of CRhinoPolyEdge::GetEdge().

member.name: P:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.ObjectCount
member.summary: Gets the number of objects that were selected.

member.name: P:Rhino.Input.Custom.GetObject.SerialNumber
member.summary: Each instance of GetObject has a unique runtime serial number that is used to identify object selection events associated with that instance.

member.name: T:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter
member.summary: If an object passes the geometry TYPE filter, then the geometry ATTRIBUTE filter is applied.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.WireCurve
member.summary: 3d wire curve If you want to accept only wire or edge curves, then specify wire_curve or edge_curve, otherwise both wire and edge curves will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.EdgeCurve
member.summary: 3d curve of a surface edge If you want to accept only wire or edge curves, then specify wire_curve or edge_curve, otherwise both wire and edge curves will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.ClosedCurve
member.summary: Closed Curves and Edges are acceptable If you want to accept only closed or open curves, then specify either closed_curve or open_curve. Otherwise both closed and open curves will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.OpenCurve
member.summary: Open Curves and Edges are acceptable If you want to accept only closed or open curves, then specify either closed_curve or open_curve. Otherwise both closed and open curves will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.SeamEdge
member.summary:
seam edges are acceptable attributes of acceptable trimming edge objects (associated with an ON_BrepTrim).
If none of these attributes are explicitly specified, then any kind of trimming edge will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.ManifoldEdge
member.summary:
edges with 2 different surfaces pass attributes of acceptable trimming edge objects (associated with an ON_BrepTrim).
If none of these attributes are explicitly specified, then any kind of trimming edge will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.NonmanifoldEdge
member.summary:
edges with 3 or more surfaces pass attributes of acceptable trimming edge objects (associated with an ON_BrepTrim).
If none of these attributes are explicitly specified, then any kind of trimming edge will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.MatedEdge
member.summary:
any mated edge passes attributes of acceptable trimming edge objects (associated with an ON_BrepTrim).
If none of these attributes are explicitly specified, then any kind of trimming edge will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.SurfaceBoundaryEdge
member.summary:
boundary edges on surface sides pass attributes of acceptable trimming edge objects (associated with an ON_BrepTrim).
If none of these attributes are explicitly specified, then any kind of trimming edge will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.TrimmingBoundaryEdge
member.summary:
boundary edges that trim a surface pass attributes of acceptable trimming edge objects (associated with an ON_BrepTrim).
If none of these attributes are explicitly specified, then any kind of trimming edge will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.BoundaryEdge
member.summary:
ant boundary edge passes attributes of acceptable trimming edge objects (associated with an ON_BrepTrim).
If none of these attributes are explicitly specified, then any kind of trimming edge will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.ClosedSurface
member.summary: If you want to accept only closed or open surfaces, then specify either closed_surface or open_surface. Otherwise both closed and open surfaces will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.OpenSurface
member.summary: If you want to accept only closed or open surfaces, then specify either closed_surface or open_surface. Otherwise both closed and open surfaces will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.TrimmedSurface
member.summary: If you want to accept only trimmed or untrimmed surfaces, then specify either trimmed_surface or untrimmed_surface. Otherwise both trimmed and untrimmed surfaces will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.UntrimmedSurface
member.summary: If you want to accept only trimmed or untrimmed surfaces, then specify either trimmed_surface or untrimmed_surface. Otherwise both trimmed and untrimmed surfaces will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.SubSurface
member.summary: If you want to accept only sub-surfaces of (multi-surface) polysrf, then specify sub_surface. If you do not want to accept sub-surfaces, then specify top_surface. Otherwise sub-surfaces and top surfaces will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.TopSurface
member.summary: If you want to accept only sub-surfaces of (multi-surface) polysrf, then specify sub_surface. If you do not want to accept sub-surfaces, then specify top_surface. Otherwise sub-surfaces and top surfaces will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.ManifoldPolysrf
member.summary: If you want to accept only manifold or nonmanifold polysrfs, then specify manifold_polysrf or nonmanifold_polysrf. Otherwise both manifold and nonmanifold polysrfs will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.NonmanifoldPolysrf
member.summary: If you want to accept only manifold or nonmanifold polysrfs, then specify manifold_polysrf or nonmanifold_polysrf. Otherwise both manifold and nonmanifold polysrfs will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.ClosedPolysrf
member.summary: If you want to accept only closed or open polysrfs, then specify either closed_polysrf or open_polysrf. Otherwise both closed and open polysrfs will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.OpenPolysrf
member.summary: If you want to accept only closed or open polysrfs, then specify either closed_polysrf or open_polysrf. Otherwise both closed and open polysrfs will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.ClosedMesh
member.summary: If you want to accept only closed or open meshs, then specify either closed_mesh or open_mesh. Otherwise both closed and open meshs will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.OpenMesh
member.summary: If you want to accept only closed or open meshs, then specify either closed_mesh or open_mesh. Otherwise both closed and open meshs will pass the attribute filter.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.BoundaryInnerLoop
member.summary: all trimming edges are boundary edges.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.MatedInnerLoop
member.summary: all trimming edges are mated.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.InnerLoop
member.summary: any inner loop is acceptable.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.Custom.GeometryAttributeFilter.BoundaryOuterLoop
member.summary: all trimming edges are boundary edges.

member.summary: all trimming edges are mated.

summary.para: Represents a dictionary class that can be attached to objects and can be serialized (saved) at necessity.

remarks.para: This is the layout of this object:

member.name: M:Rhino.Collections.ArchivableDictionary.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes an instance of a dictionary for writing to a 3dm archive.

member.summary: Initializes an instance of a dictionary for writing to a 3dm archive

member.name: M:Rhino.Collections.ArchivableDictionary.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes an instance of a dictionary for writing to a 3dm archive.
member.param: Custom version used to help the plug-in developer determine which version of a dictionary is being written. One good way to write version information is to use a date style integer (YYYYMMDD)

member.name: M:Rhino.Collections.ArchivableDictionary.#ctor(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Initializes an instance of a dictionary for writing to a 3dm archive.

Optional name to associate with this dictionary. NOTE: if this dictionary is set as a subdictionary, the name will be changed to the subdictionary key entry

member.summary: Reads a dictionary from an archive.

member.returns: new filled dictionary on success. null on failure.

member.exception: Key is null.
member.returns: true if the element is successfully found and removed; otherwise, false. This method returns false if key is not found.

member.name: P:Rhino.FileIO.BinaryArchiveWriter.Archive3dmVersion
member.summary: If a 3dm archive is being read or written, then this is the version of the 3dm archive format (1, 2, 3, 4 or 5). 0 a 3dm archive is not being read/written 1 a version 1 3dm archive is being read/written 2 a version 2 3dm archive is being read/written 3 a version 3 3dm archive is being read/written 4 a version 4 3dm archive is being read/written 5 an old version 5 3dm archive is being read 50 a version 5 3dm archive is being read/written.

member.name: M:Rhino.FileIO.BinaryArchiveReader.Dump3dmChunk(Rhino.FileIO.TextLog)
member.summary: Fnction for studying contents of a file. The primary use is as an aid to help dig through files that have been damaged (bad disks, transmission errors, etc.) If an error is found, a line that begins with the word "ERROR" is printed.
member.param: log where information is printed to
member.returns: 0 if something went wrong, otherwise the typecode of the chunk that was just studied.

member.name: T:Rhino.Input.RhinoGet
member.summary:
Base class for GetObject, GetPoint, GetSphere, etc.
You will never directly create a RhinoGet but you will use its member functions after calling GetObject::GetObjects(), GetPoint::GetPoint(), and so on.
Provides tools to set command prompt, set command options, and specify if the "get" can optionally accept numbers, nothing (pressing enter), and undo.

member.returns: true if a getter is currently active.

if true, the user can press enter.
member.returns: Commands.Result.Success - got point Commands.Result.Nothing - user pressed enter Commands.Result.Cancel - user cancel point getting.
member.remarks: If you need options or more advanced user interface, then use GetPoint class.

member.summary: User specified an option - call Option() to get option index.

member.summary: User entered a real number - call Number() to get value.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.GetResult.Color
member.summary: User entered a color - call Color() to get value.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.GetResult.Undo
member.summary: User pressed undo.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.GetResult.Miss
member.summary: User clicked and missed.

member.summary: User picked 3d point - call Point() to get 3d point.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.GetResult.Point2d
member.summary: User picked 2d window point in CRhinoGetPoint::Get2dPoint() call ON_2dPoint() to get the point and View() to get the view.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.GetResult.Line2d
member.summary: User picked a 2d line in CRhinoGetPoint::Get2dLine() call Line2d() to get the line and View() to get the view.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.GetResult.Rectangle2d
member.summary: User picked a 2d rectangle in CRhinoGetPoint::Get2dRectangle() call Rectangle2d() to get the rectangle and View() to get the view.

member.summary: User selected an object - call Object() to get object.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.GetResult.String
member.summary: User typed a string - call String() to get the string.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.GetResult.Sphere

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.GetResult.Direction
member.summary: call CRhinoGetDirection::Direction() to get the direction vector.

member.name: F:Rhino.Input.GetResult.Frame

member.name: P:Rhino.Geometry.Unroller.ExplodeOutput
member.summary: Gets or sets a value determining whether geometry should be exploded.

member.name: P:Rhino.Geometry.Unroller.ExplodeSpacing
member.summary: Gets or sets a value determining whether spacing should be exploded.

member.name: P:Rhino.Geometry.Unroller.AbsoluteTolerance
member.summary:
Gets or sets the absolute tolerance for the unrolling operation.
Absolute tolerance is used in the evaluation of new entities, such as intersections, reprojections and splits.
In the current implementation, absolute tolerance is used in tessellating rails, fitting curves and pulling back trims.

member.name: P:Rhino.Geometry.Unroller.RelativeTolerance
member.summary:
Gets or sets the relative tolerance for the unrolling operation.
Relative tolerance is used in the evaluation of intrinsic properties, such as computations "along" the surface or brep.
In the current implementation, relative tolerance is used to decide if a surface is flat enough to try to unroll. That helps ease the scale dependency. The surface has to be linear in one direction within (length * RelativeTolerance) to be considered linear for that purpose. Otherwise smash will ignore that tolerance and unroll anything.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.RhinoViewport.SetClippingPlanes(Rhino.Geometry.BoundingBox)
member.summary: Sets optimal clipping planes to view objects in a world coordinate 3d bounding box.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.RhinoViewport.SetCameraTarget(Rhino.Geometry.Point3d,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set viewport target point. By default the camera location is translated so that the camera direction vector is parallel to the vector from the camera location to the target location.
member.param: if true, the camera location is translated so that the camera direction vector is parallel to the vector from the camera location to the target location. If false, the camera location is not changed.
member.remarks: In general, Rhino users expect to have the camera direction vector and the vector from the camera location to the target location to be parallel. If you use the RhinoViewport functions to set the camera location, camera direction, and target point, then the relationship between these three points and vectors is automatically maintained. If you directly manipulate the camera properties, then you should carefully set the target by calling SetTarget() with updateCameraLocation=false.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.RhinoViewport.SetCameraLocations(Rhino.Geometry.Point3d,Rhino.Geometry.Point3d)
member.summary: Set viewport camera location and target location. The camera direction vector is changed so that it is parallel to the vector from the camera location to the target location.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.RhinoViewport.SetCameraLocation(Rhino.Geometry.Point3d,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set viewport camera location. By default the target location is changed so that the vector from the camera location to the target is parallel to the camera direction vector.
member.param: if true, the target location is changed so that the vector from the camera location to the target is parallel to the camera direction vector. If false, the target location is not changed. See the remarks section of RhinoViewport.SetTarget for important details.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.RhinoViewport.SetCameraDirection(Rhino.Geometry.Vector3d,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set viewport camera direction. By default the target location is changed so that the vector from the camera location to the target is parallel to the camera direction.
member.param: if true, the target location is changed so that the vector from the camera location to the target is parallel to the camera direction. If false, the target location is not changed. See the remarks section of RhinoViewport.SetTarget for important details.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.RhinoViewport.ChangeToParallelProjection(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Use this function to change projections of valid viewports from persective to parallel. It will make common additional adjustments to the frustum so the resulting views are similar. The camera location and direction will not be changed.
member.param: true if you want the resulting frustum to be symmetric.
member.returns: If the current projection is parallel and bSymmetricFrustum, FrustumIsLeftRightSymmetric() and FrustumIsTopBottomSymmetric() are all equal, then no changes are made and true is returned.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.RhinoViewport.ChangeToPerspectiveProjection(System.Boolean,System.Double)
member.summary: Use this function to change projections of valid viewports from parallel to perspective. It will make common additional adjustments to the frustum and camera location so the resulting views are similar. The camera direction and target point are not be changed.
member.param: true if you want the resulting frustum to be symmetric.

(pass 50.0 when in doubt) 35 mm lens length to use when changing from parallel to perspective projections. If the current projection is perspective or lens_length is <= 0.0, then this parameter is ignored.
member.returns: If the current projection is perspective and bSymmetricFrustum, FrustumIsLeftRightSymmetric() and FrustumIsTopBottomSymmetric() are all equal, then no changes are made and true is returned.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.RhinoViewport.ChangeToPerspectiveProjection(System.Double,System.Boolean,System.Double)
member.summary: Use this function to change projections of valid viewports from parallel to perspective. It will make common additional adjustments to the frustum and camera location so the resulting views are similar. The camera direction and target point are not be changed.
member.param: If RhinoMath.UnsetValue this parameter is ignored. Otherwise it must be > 0 and indicates which plane in the current view frustum should be perserved.
true if you want the resulting frustum to be symmetric.

(pass 50.0 when in doubt) 35 mm lens length to use when changing from parallel to perspective projections. If the current projection is perspective or lens_length is <= 0.0, then this parameter is ignored.
member.returns: If the current projection is perspective and bSymmetricFrustum, FrustumIsLeftRightSymmetric() and FrustumIsTopBottomSymmetric() are all equal, then no changes are made and true is returned.

member.summary:
Gets the parent view, if there is one
Every RhinoView has an associated RhinoViewport that does all the 3d display work. Those associated viewports return the RhinoView as their parent view. However, RhinoViewports are used in other image creating contexts that do not have a parent RhinoView. If you call ParentView, you MUST check for NULL return values.

member.name: P:Rhino.Display.RhinoViewport.Id
member.summary: Unique id for this viewport.

member.name: P:Rhino.Display.RhinoViewport.ChangeCounter
member.summary: The value of change counter is incremented every time the view projection or construction plane changes. The user can the mouse and nestable view manipulation commands to change a view at any time. The value of change counter can be used to detect these changes in code that is sensitive to the view projection.

member.name: P:Rhino.Display.RhinoViewport.Size
member.summary: Gets or sets the height and width of the viewport (in pixels)

member.name: P:Rhino.Display.RhinoViewport.Name
member.summary: Name associated with this viewport.

member.name: P:Rhino.Display.RhinoViewport.CameraTarget
member.summary: Viewport target point.

member.name: P:Rhino.Display.RhinoViewport.IsPlanView
member.summary: true if construction plane z axis is parallel to camera direction.

member.name: P:Rhino.Display.RhinoViewport.CameraX
member.summary: Gets the "unit to the right" vector.

member.name: P:Rhino.Display.RhinoViewport.CameraY
member.summary: Gets the "unit up" vector.

member.name: P:Rhino.Display.RhinoViewport.CameraZ
member.summary: Gets the unit vector in CameraDirection.

member.name: P:Rhino.Display.RhinoViewport.FrustumAspect
member.summary: Gets the width/height ratio of the frustum.

member.name: P:Rhino.Display.RhinoViewport.Bounds
member.summary: Gets the size and location of the viewport, in pixels, relative to the parent view.

member.name: P:Rhino.Display.RhinoViewport.ScreenPortAspect

member.name: T:Rhino.Display.VisualAnalysisMode
member.summary:
Represents a base class for visual analysis modes.
This class is abstract.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.VisualAnalysisMode.Register(System.Type)
member.summary: Registers a custom visual analysis mode for use in Rhino. It is OK to call register multiple times for a single custom analysis mode type, since subsequent register calls will notice that the type has already been registered.
member.param: Must be a type that is a subclass of VisualAnalysisMode.
member.returns: An instance of registered analysis mode on success.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.VisualAnalysisMode.Find(System.Guid)
member.summary: Finds a visual analysis mode by guid.
member.param: The globally unique identifier to search for.
member.returns: The found visual analysis mode, or null if it was not found, or on error.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.VisualAnalysisMode.Find(System.Type)
member.summary: Finds a visual analysis mode by type.
member.returns: A visual analysis mode on success, or null on error.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.VisualAnalysisMode.EnableUserInterface(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Turns the analysis mode's user interface on and off. For Rhino's built in modes this opens or closes the modeless dialog that controls the analysis mode's display settings.
member.param: true if the inferface should be shown; false if it should be concealed.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.VisualAnalysisMode.ObjectSupportsAnalysisMode(Rhino.DocObjects.RhinoObject)
member.summary: Gets a value indicating if this visual analysis mode can be used on a given Rhino object.
member.returns: true if this mode can indeed be used on the object; otherwise false.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.VisualAnalysisMode.SetUpDisplayAttributes(Rhino.DocObjects.RhinoObject,Rhino.Display.DisplayPipelineAttributes)
member.summary: If an analysis mode needs to modify display attributes, this is the place to do it. In particular, Style==Texture, then this function must be overridden.
member.remarks: Shaded analysis modes that use texture mapping, like zebra and emap, override this function set the tex, diffuse_color, and EnableLighting parameter.
member.param: The object for which to set up attributes.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.VisualAnalysisMode.UpdateVertexColors(Rhino.DocObjects.RhinoObject,Rhino.Geometry.Mesh[])
member.summary: If Style==falseColor, then this virtual function must be overridden. Rhino calls this function when it is time for to set the false colors on the analysis mesh vertices. For breps, there is one mesh per face. For mesh objects there is a single mesh.
member.param: The object for which to update vertex colors.
An array of meshes that should be updated.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.VisualAnalysisMode.DrawCurveObject(Rhino.DocObjects.CurveObject,Rhino.Display.DisplayPipeline)
member.summary: If Style==Wireframe, then the default decomposes the curve object into nurbs curve segments and calls the virtual DrawNurbsCurve for each segment.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.VisualAnalysisMode.DrawMeshObject(Rhino.DocObjects.MeshObject,Rhino.Display.DisplayPipeline)
member.summary:
Draws one mesh. Override this method to add your custom behavior.
The default implementation does nothing.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.VisualAnalysisMode.DrawBrepObject(Rhino.DocObjects.BrepObject,Rhino.Display.DisplayPipeline)
member.summary:
Draws one brep. Override this method to add your custom behavior.
The default implementation does nothing.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.VisualAnalysisMode.DrawPointObject(Rhino.DocObjects.PointObject,Rhino.Display.DisplayPipeline)
member.summary:
Draws one point. Override this method to add your custom behavior.
The default implementation does nothing.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.VisualAnalysisMode.DrawPointCloudObject(Rhino.DocObjects.PointCloudObject,Rhino.Display.DisplayPipeline)
member.summary:
Draws one point cloud. Override this method to add your custom behavior.
The default implementation does nothing.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.VisualAnalysisMode.DrawNurbsCurve(Rhino.DocObjects.RhinoObject,Rhino.Geometry.NurbsCurve,Rhino.Display.DisplayPipeline)
member.summary:
Draws a NURBS curve. This is a good function to override for analysis modes like curvature hair display.
The default implementation does nothing.
member.param: A Rhino object corresponding to the curve.

member.name: M:Rhino.Display.VisualAnalysisMode.DrawNurbsSurface(Rhino.DocObjects.RhinoObject,Rhino.Geometry.NurbsSurface,Rhino.Display.DisplayPipeline)
member.summary:
Draws a NURBS surface. This is a good function to override to display object-related meshes.
The default implementation does nothing.

member.summary:
Draws a mesh.
The default implementation does nothing.
member.param: A Rhino object corresponding to the surface.

member.summary: Id for Rhino's built-in edge analysis mode. Brep and mesh edges are shown in a selected color.

member.summary: Id for Rhino's built-in curvature graphs analysis mode. Curvature hair is shown on curves and surfaces.

member.summary: Id for Rhino's built-in zebra stripe analysis mode. Zebra stripes are shown on surfaces and meshes.

member.name: P:Rhino.Display.VisualAnalysisMode.RhinoEmapAnalysisModeId
member.summary: Id for Rhino's built-in emap analysis mode. An environment map is shown on sufaces and meshes.

member.name: P:Rhino.Display.VisualAnalysisMode.RhinoCurvatureColorAnalyisModeId
member.summary: Id for Rhino's built-in curvature color analysis mode. Surface curvature is shown using false color mapping.

member.name: P:Rhino.Display.VisualAnalysisMode.RhinoDraftAngleAnalysisModeId
member.summary: Id for Rhino's built-in draft angle analysis mode. Draft angle is displayed using false colors.

member.name: P:Rhino.Display.VisualAnalysisMode.RhinoThicknessAnalysisModeId
member.summary: Id for Rhino's built-in thickness analysis mode.

member.name: T:Rhino.UI.LOC
member.summary: Used a placeholded which is used by LocalizationProcessor application to create contextId mapped localized strings.

member.name: M:Rhino.UI.LOC.STR(System.String)
member.summary: Strings that need to be localized should call this function. The STR function doesn't actually do anything but return the original string. The LocalizationProcessor application walks through the source code of a project and looks for LOC.STR. The function is then replaced with a call to Localization.LocalizeString using a unique context ID.

member.name: M:Rhino.UI.LOC.STR(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Similar to function.
member.returns: English name.

member.name: M:Rhino.UI.LOC.COMMANDNAME(System.String)
member.summary: Command names that need to be localized should call this function. The COMMANDNAME function doesn't actually do anything but return the original string. The LocalizationProcessor application walks through the source code of a project and looks for LOC.COMMANDNAME and builds a record for each command name for the translators that can be used by developers in a commands overridden Rhino.Commands.Command.LocalName which should call Rhino.UI.Localization.LocalizeCommandName(EnglishName)

member.name: M:Rhino.UI.LOC.CON(System.String)
member.summary: Command option name strings that need to be localized should call this function. The CON function doesn't actually do anything but return the original string. The LocalizationProcessor application walks through the source code of a project and looks for LOC.CON. The function is then replaced with a call to Localization.LocalizeCommandOptionName using a unique context ID.
member.returns: Returns localized string pair with both the English and local names set to the English value.

member.name: M:Rhino.UI.LOC.CON(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Command option name strings that need to be localized should call this function. The CON function doesn't actually do anything but return the original string. The LocalizationProcessor application walks through the source code of a project and looks for LOC.CON. The function is then replaced with a call to Localization.LocalizeCommandOptionName using a unique context ID.
member.param: [in] The object that identifies the assembly that owns the command option name.
member.returns: Returns localized string pair with both the English and local names set to the English value.

member.name: M:Rhino.UI.LOC.COV(System.String)
member.summary: Command option name strings that need to be localized should call this function. The COV function doesn't actually do anything but return the original string. The LocalizationProcessor application walks through the source code of a project and looks for LOC.COV. The function is then replaced with a call to Localization.LocalizeCommandOptionValue using a unique context ID.
member.returns: Returns localized string pair with both the English and local names set to the English value.

member.name: M:Rhino.UI.LOC.COV(System.String,System.Object)

member.returns: Returns localized string pair with both the English and local names set to the English value.
